STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 17, 2022
Jennifer Stevens
Samaritas - MID MI
Ste 200
729 W. Michigan Ave.
Jackson, MI 49201
RE: License #: CB380201255
Samaritas - MID MI
Ste 200
729 W. Michigan Ave.
Jackson, MI 49201
Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
6/8/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MMDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
One of six foster home files did not have documentation that an application was
provided at least 60 days prior to license expiration.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/9/21 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/17/21
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(d) Compliance with the licensing rules for foster homes.
One of six foster home reevaluations did not accurately document rule compliance.
The home had not practiced emergency procedures as required. However, the
agency did not cite this, or develop a CAP.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/9/21 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/17/21
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
One of three special evaluations did not meet this requirement. The intake occurred
on 11/10/21, but the agency did not notify the department with a DCWL-259 until
11/18/21.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/9/21 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/17/21
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) For a child under 2 years of age, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 3 months before
4

being placed in foster care or a new physical examination shall
be completed within 30 calendar days after being placed in
foster care.
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
(f)The provision of a dental reexamination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following: (i) A dental examination within 12
months before placement or a new dental examination shall be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after placement.
(1,c) Three of nine FC and IL files did not meet this requirement.
File one: A medical is overdue as the last one was completed in April 2020.
File two: A medical is overdue as the last one was completed when the child was
previously in foster care in 2019.
File three: A medical is overdue as the last one was completed on 12/16/20. Case
notes indicate a medical was completed on 11/30/21. However, there is not
documentation to verify this occurred.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/9/21 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/17/21
(1, f) Two of nine FC and IL files did not meet this requirement.
File one: Youth did not have any dental exams completed since coming into care.
File two: Did not have a dental exam completed since their prior placement in care in
2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/15/20 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/30/20
8/9/21 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/17/21
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(2) An agency shall have documentation from the medical or
dental provider of all medical and dental care received by a
foster child.
One of nine IL and FC case files reviewed did not meet this requirement. The
treatment plan notes a well-child check on 9/30/21. However, there is not any
accompanying documentation to verify this visit.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child: (parts a-j)
5

One of six foster care files did not have a completed placement checklist, detailing
the required information.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/9/21 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/17/21
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Three of twelve updated service plans were 13-34 days late.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/15/20 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/30/20
8/9/21 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/17/21
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing
agency to another child placing agency, a modified service plan
must be completed within 30 calendar days of the change in
agency responsibility if no other plan is done within 30 days.
Three of six foster care cases did not have modified service plans completed within
30 days of case acceptance.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(6) Service plans shall be signed by the social services worker
and the social services supervisor.
One of twelve FC service plans was not signed by the social services worker.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(b),
shall include all of the following information:
(c) A summary of information pertinent to the updated
services plan received since the last service plan from the child,
the child's parents or legal guardian, foster parents, referring
agency, and others, unless the agency documents why any of
these entities cannot be involved.
One of twelve service plans did not have all of the required information updated. The
medical section of the service plan was blank.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at least once
every month.
6

Two of six foster care cases did not have monthly foster home visits documented as
required.
File one: Missing a September 2021 visit.
File two: Missing an August 2021 visit.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/9/21 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/17/21
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(c) Provisions for visits between parents and children except
where parental rights have been terminated or when there is a
court determination that visits are detrimental to the child.
One of six foster care files did not have parenting time documented as required.
Parenting time for the mother was missing for May 2022. Parenting time for the
father was missing for September 2021, March, April, and May 2022.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(d) Provisions for visits between siblings who are not placed
together except when there is a court determination that visits
are detrimental to either child.
One of six foster care files did not have sibling visits documented for March or April
2022.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/9/21 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/17/21
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
One of six IL files did not have documentation that a copy of the program statement
was provided to the youth.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency's policies and procedures required by this
rule.
One of six IL files did not have documentation that a copy of the policies and
procedures were provided to the youth.
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
7

(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service worker
and the youth in independent living at least once each month at
a youth's place of residence.
Three of three IL files had missing monthly face-to-face contact with the IL youth.
File one: Missing contact for November 2021.
File two: Missing contact for September 2021.
File three: Missing contact for September 2021.
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying
with the terms of the contract required by R 400.125010,
continues to reside in a safe and acceptable environment, and
is managing expenditures.
Three of three IL files did not meet this requirement.
File one: Missing monthly budges for September and November 2021.
File two: Did not have any monthly budgets documented.
File three: Did not have any monthly budgets documented and also did not have
information documented that monthly visits found the placement to be “safe and
acceptable”.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/9/21 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/17/21
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Two of three IL files did not meet this requirement.
File one: File did not have any contracts on file from August to December 2021.
File two: File did not have any quarterly reviewed contracts on file, after the initial IL
contract at placement in 2021.
PA116 Child Care Organizations Act 116 of 1973
722.120 section
10.3
Except as otherwise provided in this subsection and subsection
(4), records regarding children and facts compiled about
children and their parents and relatives are confidential and
disclosure of this information must be properly safeguarded by
the child care organization, the department, and any other entity
in possession of the information.
One of twenty-one USPs held case information that detailed Children’s Protective
Services history for several relatives of the foster child. This information included full
names, dates, alleged victim names, substance use, allegations, and outcomes.
This information can be entered in MiSACWIS, as necessary. But must be kept
confidential and cannot be in a USP case contact.
8

One of three foster home special evaluations reported that Children’s Protective
Services was involved with the family’s investigation.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
722-06B Family Team Meeting: Semi-Annual Transition Meeting
Page 5
Within 30 calendar days after the youth’s 14th birthday and
every six months thereafter.
For youth entering out-of-home placement at age 14 or older,
the semi-annual transition meeting must be held within 30
calendar days of the removal date; see this item for specific
meeting requirements.
Three of nine IL and FC files did not meet this requirement.
File one: Did not have a transition plan completed from February to December 2021.
File two: Did not have any transition plans completed.
File three: Did not have any transition plans completed since 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/15/20 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/30/20
722-08D Treatment Plans
Page 9-10
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable…
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Four of nine IL and FC files did not meet this requirement. Nine of twenty-one
PATPs had late or missing signatures.
722-08 Case Service Plans
Page 11
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
Five of twenty-one FC and IL service plans were approved late. Four of the service
plan approvals were 5-30 days late. One service plan completed 5/13/21, had not
been approved as of this review date.
9

722-06H Case Contacts
Page 17
The caseworker must meet with their supervisor at least
monthly for case consultation on every assigned case. Monthly
case consultation may be conducted in person or by video
conference. Monthly case consultations must be identified in
MiSACWIS with the case contact type of supervision
Three of nine IL and FC files did not have supervision documented as required.
File one: Did not have supervision contacts from July to December 2021.
File two: Did not have contacts from September to December 2021.
File three: Did not have contacts for October and November 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/15/20 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/30/20
722-06B Family Team Meetings
Page 5
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment: Updated Case Plan
(USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Six of nine IL and FC files did not have FTMs completed as required.
File one: FTMs were not documented prior to the completion of three USPs.
File two: FTM was not documented prior to the completion of one USP.
File three: FTMs were not documented prior to the completion of three USPs.
File four: FTMs were not documented prior to the completion of three USPs.
File five: FTMs were not documented prior to the completion of two USPs.
File six: FTMs were not documented prior to the completion of two USPs.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/15/20 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/30/20
801-01 Health Requirements
Page 3
Dental examinations are required for children one year of age
and older, as follows:
• A dental examination within three months before entry into
foster care or an initial dental examination must be completed
not more than 90 calendar days after entry into a foster care
out-of-home placement.
• A dental re-examination must be obtained at least every six
months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
Four of nine IL and FC files did not meet this requirement.
File one: Youth turned one year of age in July 2021 and has not had a dental exam
as of this review.
File two: Youth had a dental exam on 6/21/21, a follow-up six-month exam was late
on 4/20/22.
10

File three: Youth had a dental exam in January 2021. Two six-month exams should
have been completed since that time.
File four: Youth had a dental exam in July 2021, a follow-up six-month exam was not
completed until 4/6/22.
722-08E Action Summary
Pages 2-5
(page 2) Within three business days of change in caseworker or
organization, the new caseworker must document the following
for the former and new caseworker…
(page 3) Three days prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change,
the caseworker must document…
(page 5) Within three business days of a temporary break from
placement, the caseworker must document: • The type of
temporary break. AWOLP.
Four of six open FC case files did not meet this requirement.
(Page 2) File one: A case transfer on 9/1/21 did not have a DHS-69 completed until
9/8/21.
(Page 2) File two: A DHS-69 was not completed for a caseworker change in
November 2021.
(Page 3) File three: A 10/12/21 move was not documented on a DHS-69 until
10/19/21. In addition, the supervisor’s signature was missing from the form.
(Page 5) File four: An AWOL on 5/7/22 did not have a DHS-69 completed until
6/15/22.
722-03C Casey life skills
Page 1
The Casey Life Skills Assessment must be completed within 90
days of a youth turning 14, and annually thereafter.
Two of three IL files did not meet this requirement.
File one: Did not have any Casey Life Skill Assessments completed.
File two: Had one assessment completed on 6/3/22, but none prior.
722-06H Case contact
Page 19
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts…
All other case contacts must be entered prior to the report
period end date on the applicable case service plan.
Eight of nine FC and IL case files had late contact entry in MiSACWIS. Contacts
were entered 5-40 days late. Two supervision contacts from November and
December 2021 were not entered until June 2022.
11

722-03D Placement Change
Page 4
The caregiver must be notified of the intent to move the child 14
days prior to the intended date of the move unless the child’s
health or safety is jeopardized. The DHS-30, Foster
Parent/Caregiver Notification of Move, must be used to notify
the caregiver of the intent to move the child.
The DHS-30 must be uploaded to MiSACWIS in the document
hyperlink in the child's placement record.
One of six foster care files did not have a DHHS-30 Notification Of Move completed
and uploaded.
801-03 Medical Passport
Page 2-3
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is a temporary court
ward. Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement. At
reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
Five of six FC files did not have Medical Passports completed as required.
File one: Missing a medical passport from December 2021
File two: Missing a medical passport from April 2022.
File three: No medical passports on file.
File four: Missing documentation that a medical passport was provided to the foster
parent within the first two weeks of placement.
File five: Quarterly updated medical passports missing between December 2021 and
June 2022. In addition, the 12/20/21 medical passport did not have the parent’s
signatures or indication it was provided to them.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/15/20 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/30/20
722-03E Placement Exception Requests and Approvals
Page 2-7
Siblings in out-of-home placement must be placed together
unless circumstances exist that allow for an exception.
The explanation that supports the split sibling placement must
be documented in the narrative section of the PER.
Approval Path for PAFC-Supervised Cases 1. PAFC
caseworker completes and routes the PER. 2. PAFC supervisor
reviews and routes the PER. 3. PAFC director reviews and
routes the PER. 4. MDHHS county director or child welfare
director reviews and approves the PER.
12

One of six FC files did not have a sibling split exception request completed as
required. Placement occurred on 3/8/22. A request was not completed until 6/2/22
and was not approved as of this review.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/15/20 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/30/20
722-06H Case Contacts
Page 9-10
(Page 9) The primary foster care caseworker must have at least
two face-to face contacts with the legal parent or guardian, with
at least one contact occurring at the parent or guardian's home
or living environment, during the first month following initial out-
of-home placement.
(Page 10) The primary foster care caseworker must have face-
to-face contact with the legal parent or guardian at least once
per calendar month. At least one contact each quarter must
occur in the parent’s residence.
(Page 9) One of six FC files did not have documentation of a parental home visit
within the first month of the case.
(Page 10) One of six FC files did not have quarterly visits to the parental home since
September 2021.
801-01 Health Requirements
Page 3
After the initial medical examination upon entering foster care,
all children require an EPSDT/well child exam according to the
periodicity schedule recommended by the AAP. • For children
under three years old, the periodicity schedule for EPSDT/well
child exams is as follows: Newborn - one week of age. Four
weeks of age. Two months of age. Four months of age. Six
months of age. Nine months of age. 12 months of age. 15
months of age. 18 months of age. 24 months of age. 30 months
of age.
One of six FC cases did not have well-child exams completed as required. The file
was missing 9-, 12-, and 15-month well-child exams.
Contract Services to be provided: Case acceptance and treatment
2.10.d.9 plan
The Contractor shall complete the following: 9) A minimum of 4
hours per week of IL instruction upon completion of the CLSA
and IL Plan and Contract. Seventy-five percent of the IL
instruction time per month must be practical hands-on
instruction as opposed to classroom, worksheet, or online
instruction. In addition, 10% of the IL instruction time must be
community based.
13

Two of three IL files did not meet this requirement as there was not documentation
of four hours per week of IL instruction.
Contract Services to be provided: Case acceptance and treatment
2.10.d.8 plan
The Contractor shall complete the following: 8) Life Skills
training that will assist the youth in gaining self-sufficiency,
including applicable CLSA pre- and post-testing. The Contractor
shall document the ability of the youth to demonstrate these
skills through real life applications.
Two of three IL files did not meet this requirement as there was not documentation
of life skills training including the CLSA testing.
Contract Continuing Eligibility Criteria
1.1b
If the projected length of stay exceeds twelve months, the
Contractor shall submit the ILP Extension Request form (DHS-
786), at least 45 days prior to the twelve-month expiration date
for local office approval.
One of three IL files did not meet this requirement. The youth has been in ILP for
over twelve months. However, a DHHS-786 has not been completed.
Contract Services to be provided: Case acceptance and treatment
2.10.d.10 plan
The Contractor shall complete the following: 10) Quarterly
meetings with the case manager, youth, life skills coach, and
any supportive persons identified by the youth to review the
CLSA and the pre and post test results.
Two of three IL files did not document a quarterly meeting with the required parties
to review/discuss the CLSA results.
Contract Services to be provided: Case acceptance and treatment
2.10.d.6 plan
The Contractor shall complete the following: 6) A minimum of
four monthly contacts with the youth. This shall consist of at
least two face-to-face contacts, of which, one will be in the
youth’s residence. Each face-to-face contact shall be a
minimum of one hour. Remaining required contacts may be
conducted in person or via telephone conversation for any
length of time. Phone messages, texts, e-mails, or social media
contacts do not replace a required contact but can be utilized.
Two of three IL files did not meet this requirement.
File one: Missing a second face-to-face monthly contact for both November and
December 2021.
14

File two: Missing the second face-to-face monthly contact for September, October,
November 2021, and February 2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 The foster home rules compliance record 3080, transaction record 3706, and
reevaluation report recommendations should all match regarding, age,
gender, capacity, and type of children to be placed.
 The Borrowed Bed checklist form should have the itemized boxes checked or
initialed by the foster parent at the time of placement.
 Special evaluation reports need to code CPS involvement, by using DHHS,
Children’s Services, or another variation.
 When assessing relatives for placement, confidential information must be
protected and stored in MISACWIS in a manner that will not merge onto the
family’s service plan.
 FTM 1105 reports must identify who participated and how: in person, by
phone, video conference, etc.
 If a foster parent refuses to sign a DHHS-30 Notification of Move, the agency
must indicate this on the form and upload as required.
 Parenting time contacts- if parenting time did not occur, the contact entry
must indicate the reason: parent cancelled, FP sick, child sick, etc.
 Licensing workers should review the prior years licensing evaluation, prior to
completing a reevaluation, to determine any issues that require follow-up.
 Per contract, Youth in ILP must be evaluated with the CLSA every 90 days to
determine if they continue to be eligible for ILP, or if they are able to transition
to general IL.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation.
15

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
One special evaluation, completed on 2/8/22, determined the foster parent was in
violation of rule 404 Behavior Management and rule 201 Foster Parent
Qualifications. This violation was due to the foster parent consuming alcohol and
accidentally scratching her son, in front of the foster child. A CAP was developed
and completed on 5/4/22. The CAP included monthly contact with the licensing
worker, grief counseling, individual therapy, anger management class, alcohol
education course, a substance abuse assessment, and a psychological evaluation.
Overall, it was determined the agency handled the special evaluation appropriately
and addressed the underlying issue of the caregiver’s grief over a recent loss. There
were no prior investigations with this foster home and there have been no further
concerns since.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. After the 8/9/21 interim review, a CAP
was developed and approved on 9/17/21. During this review, it was determined the
agency has minimal compliance with their CAP. This is reportedly due to ongoing
staffing issues. The Chief Administrator reported difficulty in implementing CAP
items, as staff turn-over had been high. While new staff have recently been hired,
they require time to get into routines. In 2021 the agency was found to have 29 rule
and contract/policy violations. During this 2022 review 38 violations were found,
including 10 repeat violations from 2021 and 7 repeat violations from 2020. The
agency was advised that improvement in the repeat violations is necessary over the
next review period. The agency must develop a strong CAP, with measurable action
steps to address all violations. It was advised that once the CAP is approved, the
agency should review the CAP and discuss it often with staff and supervisors. The
agency should also determine strategies to monitor and review certain items to
ensure they are being completed thoroughly and timely. As always, DCWL is
available to provide consultation for any of these areas. Not only during the CAP
development, but on an ongoing basis.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed with the Chief
Administrator. The Chief Administrator (CA) reported struggling this year due to
significant staff turnover, including supervisory positions. Hiring continues to be
difficult due to a lack of qualified applicants, as has been seen throughout the state.
CA stated restructuring of the management team has occurred. Plans for retention
and increased staff oversight are also being developed. In addition, the agency has
been slow to accept new placements, as they want to improve their staffing stability,
before increasing their case numbers. CA identified some of the areas they have
16

had difficulty with including obtaining PATP and medical passport signatures,
obtaining medical/dental documentation from offices, case contact entry, general
documentation, and ILP specific documentation. CA has also identified some areas
that have shown improvement, including borrowed bed files, supervisor tracking of
service plans, worker/supervisor contacts, worker/child contacts, and FTM
completion- although it was noted documentation in the system has not been
completed as required. CA believes the agency continues to do good work and has
shown improvement over recent months, although it may not be reflected in this
review. The CA is confident that the recent transfer of a FC Supervisor to this office
from another region, will assist with showing marked improvement over the next
year.
Interviews
Three staff were interviewed on-site. Staff reported being employed with the agency
between two months and one year. Staff stated their caseloads were manageable,
their supervisors helpful, knowledgeable, and able to communicate well. Overall,
they reported the agency was a great place to work. None of the staff expressed any
concerns. However, the newer staff stated that more job shadowing or hands-on
training would be beneficial.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, and contract/policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be
issued a renewal of their regular license.
